papers.abstract: This paper considers food delivery work as a form of piecework that is conducted via a particular workflow system – the food delivery platform and its delivery app. We offer an ethnographic account of food delivery labor during the early phases of the COVID-19 pandemic in the Indian city of Pune. Our inquiry is focused on (1) the workflow that structures food delivery work and (2) how economic considerations shape how workers work with and around the workflow. Our findings depict both the workflow that structures the delivery work and the efforts workers make beyond it to deal with contingencies and unexpected requirements they encounter on the ground. We recognize the workers' efforts as essential to make the workflow work but also to make the piecework arrangement work for them. We highlight how, in this setting, money is not just the motivation for engaging in gig work; rather, economic considerations infuse every aspect of the work process. Acknowledging the distinct shape gig work takes in a Global South context, our study highlights the value of in-depth,in situ understandings of how gig workers' economic considerations are entangled with their interactions with the technology that structures their work. Our key contribution lies in mapping outthe workflow of piecework and the work to make piecework work, specifically in a Global South setting, by drawing upon classic CSCW themes around workflows and piecework to strengthen the contemporary scholarly discussion concerning gig work.

events.Text: We recognize the workers' efforts as essential to make the workflow work but also to make the piecework arrangement work for them. We highlight how, in this setting, money is not just the motivation for engaging in gig work; rather, economic considerations infuse every aspect of the work process.

Context: We recognize the workers' efforts as essential to make the workflow work but also to make the piecework arrangement work for them.
We highlight how, in this setting, money is not just the motivation for engaging in gig work; rather, economic considerations infuse every aspect of the work process.
Purpose: To explore the impact of economic factors on workplace dynamics and decision-making processes.
To examine how recognizing dual purposes in work setups influences understanding of worker behavior influenced by monetary incentives.
Method: Analyzing the interplay between personal effort, job characteristics, and economic variables such as income levels.
Results: Insights reflecting that considering economic factors leads to more nuanced understandings of worker behavior compared to previous studies focused solely on intrinsic motivations.
Analysis: Discussion delving into how recognizing dual purposes—both functional efficiency and personalized job arrangements—affects perceptions of compensation structures.
Challenge: Challenges including balancing diverse needs against systemic issues arising from rigid monetization frameworks.
Ethical: Ethical concerns tied to fairness concerns associated with unequal pay scales among gig workers relative to conventional employees.
Implications: Applicability across varied settings requiring tailored solutions addressing multifaceted workforce dynamics.

events.Text: Acknowledging the distinct shape gig work takes in a Global South context, our study highlights the value of in-depth, in situ understandings of how gig workers' economic considerations are entangled with their interactions with the technology that structures their work. Our key contribution lies in mapping out the workflow of piecework and the work to make piecework work, specifically in a Global South setting, by drawing upon classic CSCW themes around workflows and piecework to strengthen the contemporary scholarly discussion concerning gig work.

Primary Object: workflow of piecework and the work to make piecework work

Context: acknowledging the distinct shape gig work takes in a Global South context
Purpose: enhancing the contemporary scholarly discussion concerning gig work
Method: drawing upon classic CSCW themes around workflows and piecework
Results: a detailed framework outlining the workflow stages involved in piecework and strategies to make piecework work
Analysis: insights about how economic motivations interact with technological-mediated platforms
Implications: influencing future research directions focusing on similar issues globally

papers.abstract: Computer-Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW) and Human–Computer Interaction (HCI) research is increasingly investigating the roles of caregivers as ancillary stakeholders in patient-centered care. Our research extends this body of work to identify caregivers as key decision-makers and boundary actors in mobilizing and managing care. We draw on qualitative data collected via 20 semi-structured interviews to examine caregiving responsibilities in physical and remote care interactions within households in urban India. Our findings demonstrate the crucial intermediating roles family caregivers take on while situated along the boundaries separating healthcare professionals, patients and other household members, and online/offline communities. We propose design recommendations for supporting caregivers in intermediating patient-centered care, such as through training content and expert feedback mechanisms for remote care, collaborative tracking mechanisms integrating patient- and caregiver-generated health data, and caregiving-centered online health communities. We conclude by arguing for recognizing caregivers as critical stakeholders in patient-centered care who might constitute technologically assisted pathways to care.

events.Text: Computer-Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW) and Human–Computer Interaction (HCI) research is increasingly investigating the roles of caregivers as ancillary stakeholders in patient-centered care. Our research extends this body of work to identify caregivers as key decision-makers and boundary actors in mobilizing and managing care.

Context: extending this body of work to identify caregivers as key decision-makers and boundaryactors in mobilizing and managing care
Purpose: understand the role of caregivers as key decision-makers and boundaryactors in mobilizing and managing care
Method: qualitative methods involving interviews and case studies across diverse populations
Results: findings show that caregivers play crucial roles in both making decisions regarding patients’ treatment plans and setting boundaries between personal and professional interactions during care management
Analysis: interpretations explore deeper insights into why these dynamics occur among caregivers
Implications: findings suggest broader applications for improving healthcare support systems where recognizing and leveraging caregivers' contributions could enhance overall care quality while respecting their autonomy

events.Text: We draw on qualitative data collected via 20 semi-structured interviews to examine caregiving responsibilities in physical and remote care interactions within households in urban India.

Agent: Qualitative data collection via 20 semi-structured interviews was conducted.

Primary Object: Data collected from 20 semi-structured interviews was analyzed.

Context: The analysis focuses on caregiving responsibilities during physical and remote care interactions within households in urban India.
Purpose: To examine the impact of caregiving responsibilities in both physical and remote care settings within Indian households.
Method: Qualitative data was gathered through 20 semi-structured interviews.
Results: Findings revealed patterns in caregiving dynamics between physical and remote care environments.
Analysis: These patterns highlight differences in support-seeking behaviors depending on the mode of care utilized.
Challenge: Limitations include small sample size and potential bias due to self-reported nature of data.
Ethical: Ensures respect for participants' privacy and informed consent was obtained.
Implications: This study contributes insights applicable to understanding caregiving roles post-pandemic digitalization trends globally.
Contradictions: No contradictions noted with existing literature on caregiving dynamics.

events.Text: Our findings demonstrate the crucial intermediating roles family caregivers take on while situated along the boundaries separating healthcare professionals, patients and other household members, and online/offline communities.
events.Main Action: family caregivers play crucial intermediate roles

Context: situated along the boundaries separating healthcare professionals, patients and other household members, and online/offline communities
Purpose: demonstrate the crucial intermediating roles family caregivers take
Implications: further studies exploring these interactions’ impact on patient care quality

events.Text: We propose design recommendations for supporting caregivers in intermediating patient-centered care, such as through training content and expert feedback mechanisms for remote care, collaborative tracking mechanisms integrating patient- and caregiver-generated health data, and caregiving-centered online health communities. We conclude by arguing for recognizing caregivers as critical stakeholders in patient-centered care who might constitute technologically assisted pathways to care.

Secondary Object: supporting caregivers in intermediating patient-centered care

Context: such as through training content and expert feedback mechanisms for remote care, collaborative tracking mechanisms integrating patient- and caregiver-generated health data, and caregiving-centered online health communities
Purpose: enhancing support systems for caregivers in patient-centered care
Method: training content development, creation of feedback loops between experts and caregivers, implementation of data-sharing platforms, fostering online health communities focusing on caregiving needs
Results: improvements in effective caregiving under patient-centered settings
Analysis: explanations regarding the expansion of telehealth accessibility facilitated by technological innovations enabling remote monitoring and management
Challenge: limited resources, time constraints, provider resistance
Ethical: questions about equitable access to ensure all patients benefit irrespective of socio-economic standing or geographical factors
Implications: long-term effects including refinement of clinical guidelines emphasizing family-centered approaches and increased public awareness of caregivers' pivotal role in decision-making processes
